title: Ice cold nordic look and feel
content:
Hello,

I need a typeface with ice cold nordic look and feel.  
The custom design made by [Helsinki Type Studio](http://web.archive.org/web/20150425050024/http:/www.helsinkitypestudio.com/) for the [Finnish Design Museum](http://web.archive.org/web/20150425050024/http:/www.werklig.com/solutions/design-museum/).  
As we can't find an available exact match, can I ask help to find the closest possible ?

Cheers,  
L.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [finnish\_type.png](http://web.archive.org/web/20150425050024/http:/typophile.com/files/finnish_type.png) | 255.05 KB |
author: laurent

comments.content: I wouldn’t say [this](http://web.archive.org/web/20150425050024/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/shinn/panoptica/bold-47324/) is close, but it could be used to similar effect.
I'm curious why only the S was made angular.

In Alphaville?  
The design utilizes a 37˚ angled upstroke, which didn’t ﬁt the construction of the /S, so its form is orthogonal.  
(Although I did cheat with the /X, but that’s not used very much so I felt I could get away with it.)
I think he meant in that frankenfont linked in the OP.

Oh, I see.  
I like that idea.  
Similarly, one might ask why only the /I has serifs.  
So it’s not a complete anomaly.

Well, thanks for your input, not thrilled, though...  
Looks like I'll have to do my homework by myself !

Cheers,  
L.
